**Refining extraction design**

Iâ€™m thinking about parsing the list of URLs as potential location candidates. For the system design, Iâ€™ll divide the text extraction process into several key steps. Pre-processing will segment lines, remove date or time lines, and identify bullet points. Iâ€™ll utilize Named Entity Recognition (NER) tools for location identification and regex for address patterns.

Next, URLs will be extracted, deduplicated, and normalized. My agent prompt must ensure that only explicitly mentioned locations are included, while additional suggestions are treated separately, and Iâ€™ll draft specific architecture for effective extraction.
**Designing extraction methods**

Iâ€™m considering how to structure the URL extractor. For each URL, I'll skip those from Gmail but might still look for booking details in mail threads. For other domains, Iâ€™ll fetch the title and possibly some metadata using a search approach. Iâ€™ll also use regex to derive location names from slugs and store results in a data class for future use.

Here is a concrete, step-by-step plan for the â€œextractorsâ€ component and the system-/assistant-prompts that will drive the LLM-powered extractor.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
1.  OBJECTIVES & CONSTRAINTS
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
â€¢  HIGH-RECALL, HIGH-PRECISION: Capture every location that is explicitly mentioned or linked, while avoiding hallucinated / â€œhelpful extraâ€ places.  
â€¢  STRICT SOURCE TIE-BACK: Every location in the output must be traceable to (a) an exact text span or (b) a specific URL in the userâ€™s input.  
â€¢  NO PROACTIVE ADDITIONS: The only time weâ€™d add unseen places is when the text explicitly invites it (e.g. â€œplease add other museumsâ€¦â€).  
â€¢  MINIMAL OUTPUT: For the extraction phase we only need the skeletal fields that will allow later enrichers/geocoders to work:
  â€“ name (string, required â€“ best guess / â€œunknownâ€ if weâ€™re not sure)  
  â€“ address_or_hint (string, optional)  
  â€“ source_type (â€œtextâ€ | â€œurlâ€)  
  â€“ source_snippet_or_url (string)  
  â€“ confidence (float 0-1)  

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
2.  PIPELINE DESIGN
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
TextExtractor.extract(text)
  a.  Pre-processing
      â€¢ Split into lines, keep original ordering & indices.  
      â€¢ Regex-extract URLs early so we donâ€™t feed them to the NER twice.  
      â€¢ Normalise whitespace, keep date/time lines for context (theyâ€™re sometimes addresses).  
  b.  Line-level heuristics
      â€¢ Regexes for full addresses: â€œ\d+ .+?, \d{4,5} .+?â€  
      â€¢ â€œmeet us at:â€ â†’ capture rest of line.  
      â€¢ â€œStaying atâ€ / â€œStay atâ€ â†’ capture remainder.  
  c.  Named-Entity Recognition
      â€¢ Run spaCy (en_core_web_sm is good enough) limited to entity labels {GPE, LOC, FAC}.  
      â€¢ For each entity keep (text, start_line, label, sentence) for later merging.  
  d.  Post-processing & merge
      â€¢ De-duplicate (case-insensitive, strip punctuation).  
      â€¢ Merge entities that appear in the same sentence (â€œEiffel Towerâ€ + â€œParisâ€ â†’ keep Eiffel Tower, attach city=â€Parisâ€ as metadata if wanted).  
      â€¢ Assign confidence: heuristics > NER (0.9) / NER alone (0.7) / fuzzy (0.4).  

URLExtractor.extract(urls)
  a.  Classification
      â€¢ Gmail thread (mail.google.com) â†’ keep but treat as low confidence until enrich stage.  
      â€¢ Other domains â†’ candidate for scraping.  
  b.  Fast title fetch (requests + BeautifulSoup, 3-second timeout)
      â€¢ Parse <title> and common OG tags (og:title, twitter:title).  
      â€¢ Slug fallback: last path segment with â€œ-â€ or â€œ_â€ replaced by spaces.  
  c.  Produce same minimal record:  
      name           = cleaned title | slug | â€œunknownâ€  
      address_or_hint= â€œâ€ (unknown until enrichment)  
      source_type    = â€œurlâ€  
      source_snippet_or_url = full url  
      confidence     = 0.6 if title found else 0.3  

StructuredExtractor.extract(data)
  â€¢ Not needed yet â€“ stub remains.

Combine & expose in pipeline:
  LocationPipeline.process_text() â†’ TextExtractor â†’ return list  
  LocationPipeline.process_urls() â†’ URLExtractor â†’ return list  
  LocationPipeline.process_mixed_input() just concatenates

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
3.  AGENT PROMPTS
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
System prompt for extraction-only agent
```
You are an extraction-only agent whose sole task is to pull out locations that are
explicitly named or linked in the userâ€™s input.

Rules:
1.  Do NOT invent or add new venues unless the text *explicitly* asks for extra suggestions
    (e.g. lines starting with â€œadditionalâ€, â€œplease suggestâ€, etc.).
2.  Every extracted item must include:
      â€¢ "name": best-guess text of the location (or "unknown")
      â€¢ "address_or_hint": address, meeting point, or empty string
      â€¢ "source_type": "text" or "url"
      â€¢ "source_snippet_or_url": the exact line or the URL itself
      â€¢ "confidence": 0-1 float
3.  Preserve ALL locations, even if they look repeated or have low confidence;
    de-duplication happens later downstream.
4.  Output JSON array ONLY. No extra commentary.
5.  Think step-by-step privately but show ONLY the final JSON.
```

Assistant (scratch-pad / internal) prompt template
```
### INTERNAL THOUGHTS (not visible to end user)
[Paste user input]
Step 1: list all URLs â€¦
Step 2: line-by-line scan for "Stay at", "Meet us at" â€¦
Step 3: apply NER â€¦
Step 4: merge + build JSON â€¦
ONLY AFTER processing -> return JSON.

### FINAL ANSWER
<json>
```
The *_internal_* part is not returned; we ensure the model confines its visible output to the JSON block.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
4.  FLOW OF YOUR SAMPLE INPUT
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Example extractions (abbreviated):
```
[
  { "name": "145 Rue du Temple", "address_or_hint": "145 Rue du Temple, 75003 Paris, France",
    "source_type": "text", "source_snippet_or_url": "145 Rue du Temple, 3rd arr., 75003 Paris, France",
    "confidence": 0.9 },

  { "name": "Saint-Paul - Rue Saint-Antoine Paris", "address_or_hint": "75004",
    "source_type": "text", "source_snippet_or_url": "Please meet us at: Saint-Paul - Rue Saint-Antoine Paris, Ãle-de-France 75004",
    "confidence": 0.85 },

  { "name": "Picasso Museum", "address_or_hint": "", "source_type": "text",
    "source_snippet_or_url": "11am - Picasso Museum(order number 2312941 )",
    "confidence": 0.8 },

  { "name": "https://www.fondationlouisvuitton.fr/en/ticketing", "address_or_hint": "",
    "source_type": "url", "source_snippet_or_url": "https://www.fondationlouisvuitton.fr/en/ticketing",
    "confidence": 0.6 },

  ...
]
```
Note that *â€œadditional best museums in Londonâ€* would **not** trigger new items unless that exact phrase appears and weâ€™ve built an â€œinvitation detectorâ€.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
5.  NEXT IMPLEMENTATION TASKS
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
1.  Write the invitation-detector helper (simple keyword classifier).  
2.  Flesh out `TextExtractor.extract()` with regex + spaCy logic.  
3.  Implement fast-title fetch in `URLExtractor` using requests+bs4.  
4.  Unit tests: feed the sample text and assert that every obvious location appears.  
5.  Integrate into `LocationPipeline.process_text/process_urls`.

+ # Extractors Component â€“ Detailed Plan
+ 
+ *Last updated: 2025-07-25*
+ 
+ ## 1. Context & Typical Inputs
+ 
+ Most source documents fall into one of two shapes:
+ 
+ 1. **Partial itineraries** â€“ loosely structured day-by-day plans that mix dates, times,
+    meeting spots, URLs, and free-form notes.
+ 2. **Laundry lists / advice pages** â€“ bullet lists or paragraphs naming many points of
+    interest, sometimes with inline links.
+ 
+ The extractor must succeed on both with **high recall** and **no hallucinated extra
+ locations**.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## 2. Objectives & Constraints
+ 
+ â€¢ **High-recall, high-precision**: capture every explicitly mentioned or linked location.
+ â€¢ **Strict source tie-back**: each output item stores the exact text span or URL it
+   originated from.
+ â€¢ **No proactive additions**: only add new items when the text clearly invites extra
+   suggestions (e.g. "additional best museums â€¦").
+ â€¢ **Minimal schema for this phase**:
+ 
+ ```json
+ {
+   "name": string,               // best guess or "unknown"
+   "address_or_hint": string,    // may be empty
+   "source_type": "text" | "url",
+   "source_snippet_or_url": string,
+   "confidence": float           // 0-1
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## 3. Pipeline Design
+ 
+ ### 3.1 TextExtractor
+ 
+ 1. **Pre-processing**
+    â€¢ Split into lines, keep indices.
+    â€¢ Early regex grab of URLs to hand off to `URLExtractor`.
+ 2. **Line-level heuristics**
+    â€¢ Regex for addresses: `\d+ .+?, \d{4,5} .+?`.
+    â€¢ Key phrases: "Stay at", "Staying at", "meet us at", "Please meet us at".
+ 3. **Named-Entity Recognition**
+    â€¢ spaCy `en_core_web_sm`, entity labels {`GPE`, `LOC`, `FAC`}.
+ 4. **Post-processing & merge**
+    â€¢ Case-insensitive de-dupe.
+    â€¢ Merge nested entities ("Eiffel Tower" + "Paris").
+    â€¢ Confidence: heuristics 0.9, NER 0.7, fuzzy 0.4.
+ 
+ ### 3.2 URLExtractor
+ 
+ 1. **Classification**
+    â€¢ Gmail threads â†’ low confidence until enrichment.
+ 2. **Fast title fetch** (â‰¤3 s)
+    â€¢ `requests` + `BeautifulSoup` â†’ `<title>`, `og:title`, `twitter:title`.
+    â€¢ Fallback: slug from path.
+ 3. **Record assembly**
+    â€¢ `confidence` 0.6 if title found, else 0.3.
+ 
+ ### 3.3 StructuredExtractor
+ 
+ *Stub for future CSV/JSON/XML inputs.*
+ 
+ ### 3.4 Pipeline Glue
+ 
+ ```text
+ LocationPipeline.process_text()  -> TextExtractor
+ LocationPipeline.process_urls()  -> URLExtractor
+ LocationPipeline.process_mixed() -> concat(text, urls)
+ ```
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## 4. LLM-Agent Prompts
+ 
+ ### 4.1 System Prompt (extraction agent)
+ 
+ ```
+ You are an extraction-only agent. Your task is to list every location explicitly
+ named or linked in the user's input.
+ 
+ Rules:
+ 1. Do NOT invent locations unless the text explicitly asks for suggestions.
+ 2. For each item output:
+    â€¢ name, address_or_hint, source_type, source_snippet_or_url, confidence
+ 3. Preserve duplicates; de-duplication happens later.
+ 4. Output JSON array ONLY, no extra commentary.
+ ```
+ 
+ ### 4.2 Assistant Internal Scratch-Pad
+ 
+ ```
+ INTERNAL STEPS (not returned):
+ 1. List URLs
+ 2. Scan lines with heuristics
+ 3. Run spaCy NER
+ 4. Merge & build JSON
+ 
+ VISIBLE OUTPUT: <json>
+ ```
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## 5. Sample Walk-Through
+ 
+ Given the itinerary snippet in the design discussion, expected extractions include
+ (but are not limited to):
+ 
+ - 145 Rue du Temple, 75003 Paris
+ - Saint-Paul â€“ Rue Saint-Antoine, 75004 Paris
+ - Picasso Museum
+ - `https://www.fondationlouisvuitton.fr/en/ticketing`
+ - Eiffel Tower
+ 
+ Each record stores the exact line or URL and an appropriate confidence value.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## 6. Implementation Tasks
+ 
+ 1. Build **invitation detector** for phrases that request extra suggestions.
+ 2. Implement `TextExtractor.extract()` (regex + spaCy).
+ 3. Implement `URLExtractor.extract()` (title fetch & record build).
+ 4. Unit tests covering sample itinerary & list pages.
+ 5. Wire into `LocationPipeline` methods.
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## 7. Performance Targets
+ 
+ â€¢ â‰¤30 s per 1 000-line document (incl. URL titles).  
+ â€¢ â‰¤500 MB peak memory during extraction. 
```

**Chunk 1**

```diff
@@ -138,2 +138,87 @@
  â€¢ â‰¤30 s per 1 000-line document (incl. URL titles).  
  â€¢ â‰¤500 MB peak memory during extraction. 
+ 
+ ---
+ 
+ ## 8. Agent Implementation (OpenAI Function-Calling)
+ 
+ ### 8.1 Overview
+ 
+ We will wrap the extractor logic inside an **OpenAI ChatCompletion agent** that can
+ call Python â€œfunctionsâ€ (as described in the OpenAI function-calling interface)
+ to delegate specific subtasks that classical code handles better than the LLM.
+ 
+ The agent runs in two tiers:
+ 
+ 1. **LLM Tier** â€“ decides *which* tool to invoke and with *what* arguments, or
+    responds with the final JSON when all information is gathered.
+ 2. **Tool Tier** â€“ deterministic Python functions that perform heavy-lifting
+    (regex, spaCy NER, HTTP fetches) and return structured data back to the LLM.
+ 
+ ### 8.2 Environment & Credentials
+ 
+ Set the OpenAI key via an env var (already configured in CI/dev machines):
+ 
+ ```bash
+ export LAVI_OPENAI_KEY="sk-..."  # done via direnv or .env
+ ```
+ 
+ The agent wrapper will read:
+ 
+ ```python
+ import os, openai
+ openai.api_key = os.environ["LAVI_OPENAI_KEY"]
+ ```
+ 
+ ### 8.3 Function Registry (Tools)
+ 
+ | Name                | Purpose                               | Python Impl | Exposed Args |
+ |---------------------|---------------------------------------|-------------|--------------|
+ | `extract_entities`  | spaCy-based NER on given text chunk   | `nlp_utils.py` | `text` |
+ | `regex_addresses`   | Heuristic address regexes             | `nlp_utils.py` | `text` |
+ | `invitation_check`  | Detect if text invites extra places   | `heuristics.py` | `text` |
+ | `url_title_fetch`   | Fast title/OG scrape (<3 s)           | `net_utils.py` | `url` |
+ | `slug_to_name`      | Derive name from URL slug             | `net_utils.py` | `url` |
+ 
+ These functions return JSON-serialisable dicts / lists so the LLM can reason
+ about them.
+ 
+ ### 8.4 Agent Flow (high-level)
+ 
+ ```mermaid
+ sequenceDiagram
+   participant U as User Input
+   participant A as Chat (LLM)
+   participant T as Tools
+   U->>A: raw itinerary text + urls
+   A->>T: regex_addresses(text)
+   T-->>A: address candidates
+   A->>T: extract_entities(text)
+   T-->>A: NER entities
+   alt URLs found
+     A->>T: url_title_fetch(url)
+     T-->>A: title & metadata
+   end
+   A-->>U: final JSON array of locations
+ ```
+ 
+ ### 8.5 System Prompt (updated)
+ 
+ Add a one-liner instructing the agent to use tools when helpful:
+ 
+ > "When a tool can accomplish the task more accurately or efficiently, return a
+ >  `function_call` with the proper name and arguments."
+ 
+ Everything else in Â§4.1 still applies.
+ 
+ ### 8.6 Implementation Notes
+ 
+ â€¢ Use `openai.ChatCompletion.create(model="gpt-4o-0613", â€¦)` with
+   `functions=[â€¦], function_call="auto"`.
+ â€¢ Stream responses disabled for simplicity; handle up to ~15 k tokens per call.
+ â€¢ Retry logic with exponential back-off (HTTP 429, 5xx).
+ 
+ ### 8.7 Updated Implementation Tasks (adds 6-7)
+ 
+ 6. Build tool wrappers (`nlp_utils.py`, `net_utils.py`, `heuristics.py`).
+ 7. Implement `agent/extraction_agent.py` that orchestrates ChatCompletion calls. 
```

</details>

<details><summary>Edit file: docs/extractors_plan.md</summary>

I will add an optional sub-section describing how HF SmolAgents could be used instead of the OpenAI function-calling wrapper.

**Chunk 1**
Lines added: 28, lines removed: undefined

```diff
@@ -223,2 +223,30 @@
  6. Build tool wrappers (`nlp_utils.py`, `net_utils.py`, `heuristics.py`).
  7. Implement `agent/extraction_agent.py` that orchestrates ChatCompletion calls. 
+ 
+ ### 8.8 Alternative: Hugging Face *smol-agents*
+ 
+ If we prefer to stay entirely in open-source-only tooling, we can swap the
+ OpenAI ChatCompletion layer for Hugging Faceâ€™s *smol-agents* framework
+ ( https://github.com/huggingface/smol-agents ).  The differences:
+ 
+ | Aspect                | OpenAI Function-Calling            | HF smol-agents                              |
+ |-----------------------|------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|
+ | Model                 | `gpt-4o` via OpenAI API            | Any HF chat model (e.g. `mistralai/Mixtral`) |
+ | Tool Interface        | JSON `function_call` schema        | Python decorators (`@tool`)                 |
+ | Pricing / limits      | Pay-per-token, external service    | Local weights possible (GPU/CPU)            |
+ | Quality               | Typically higher (GPT-4)           | Depends on chosen model                     |
+ | Deployment simplicity | Minimal code, but needs API key    | Need to host/quantise model or use HF Inference API |
+ 
+ **Integration points:**
+ 
+ 1. Replace the `openai.ChatCompletion.create()` call with the smol-agents
+    `Agent` class, loading a chosen HF chat model (we can test with `HuggingFaceHub`).
+ 2. Register the same Python tool functions (`extract_entities`, `url_title_fetch`, â€¦)
+    using the `@tool` decorator.
+ 3. Adjust the system prompt slightly (smol-agents uses `AGENT_INSTRUCTIONS`).
+ 
+ No further structural changes are neededâ€”the `TextExtractor`, `URLExtractor`, and
+ pipeline remain identical.
+ 
+ *Decision pending:* we will prototype with OpenAI first for maximum quality, and
+ leave a feature flag `USE_SMOL_AGENTS=True` in `config.yaml` to switch later. 
```

</details>
